Sure sounds like they are holding your funds in a fractional reserve while collecting interest on your cash.
The company itself doesn't scam you directly in the sense that they refuse to let you withdraw etc. They scam you in a sense that they put you in a vulnerable position where you get your funds stolen and then refuse to give away the information of the scammer due to their privacy policy. If I have a business which allows some of my customers to steal freely from my other customers while I cover up for the scamming customers without making the risks clear then I am a scammer by definition:
Definition of SCAMMER. a dishonest person who uses clever means to cheat others out of something of value <Internet scammers who never seem to run out of swindles>
This is the very reason why I started the first honest freelancing website, it's the first honest financial website connected to the internet as far as I'm concerned.
I wouldn't say that these sites are scamming just because they are earning interest from your funds prior to your funds being available for your withdrawal. Users are made aware of this fact and agree to this prior to doing work for/through the site, and should rationally consider this a cost of doing business.
I would also say that just because funds are co-mingled with the company's own funds, it would not mean that they are working on a fractional reserve system, all it means they are co-mingling funds (which is a general bad practice)

TLDR
. So what's the greater evil? --- Ambiguity. Without the help of emoticons we are doomed to have our intent misinterpreted. Bitcoin Basic Concepts
Â•Bitcoin is a shared ledger system and the current state of the ledger is determined by a decentralized consensus.
Â•Bitcoin "mining" is the process of adding transactions to the ledger and is done by solving math problems that take substantial computational power.
Â•The "consensus" is achieved by users and "miners" deciding to run compatible versions of the software and enforcing the consensus rules.
Â•Users can run "nodes" using peer-2-peer connections that shares the ledger.
Â•Nodes enforce the rules by only broadcasting transactions and sections of the ledger that fit within the consensus rules.
Â•A user can verify the shared ledger took a huge amount of computational power to create as a way of trusting it is real.
Â•Miners get transaction fees and "block rewards" as an incentive to use their computer power.
Â•The "rewards" are a way to initially distribute the currency and are cut in half about every 4 years.
Â•Bitcoin addresses are secure because the numbers are so large that all the computers in the world cannot come close to cracking it.

post_problems.content:
Hello Bitcoiners!
Bitcoin Black Friday officially launches on Nov. 29th.
This is the second annual event. We had a Bitcoin Black Friday last year and had about 75 participating merchants. Here's a rundown of Bitcoin Friday results from last year.
http://codinginmysleep.com/bitcoin-friday-results/
Everyone had a great day... Let's do it again, but bigger!
This year we're aiming to get 500 (Yes, I said 500) merchants signed up and offering deals on their websites ONLY for Bitcoin users ONLY on November 29th.
For those of you who didn't participate last year, Bitcoin Friday is a one day sale two weeks before the great American pre-holiday sale: Black Friday. It is a chance to prove a couple things:
Bitcoin is not only used for buying drugs. Huge this year with all the news coverage of the Silk Road closure.
People will spend bitcoins, and not only hoard them.
That the Bitcoin community treasures its Bitcoin merchants and appreciates their work and contribution to the Bitcoin economy.
Last year we had a couple spontaneous Bitcoin Friday parties erupt (looking at you Bitcoin Kiez and Room77
). This year Bitcoin Friday will hopefully be sending packages of goodies (from BF participating merchants!) to groups that host Bitcoin Black Friday parties. Think Bitcoin Friday t-shirts, Alpaca socks, and other Bitcoin-related items. If you're interested in hosting a BBF party, let me know over PM. I'll be promoting this portion of Bitcoin Black Friday more in the next week.
So, I'd love some feedback on how the project has developed, please reply below with suggestions for this year's sale!
If you're interested in signing up for an alert when the sale begins, or listing as a merchant (it's free!) go to our website:
http://BitcoinBlackFriday.com

However, as soon as things are no longer black and white all sorts of disputes are bound to happen. Homosexual marriage or not? Sex with animals or not? Emoticons or not?
Regarding the latter, emoticons are the lesser evil in this highly pragmatic way of communication, where memes dominate the internet space and one must state their sentence with the minimal number of bytes in order to prevent people from answering with
TLDR
. So what's the greater evil? --- Ambiguity. Without the help of emoticons we are doomed to have our intent misinterpreted. The researchers collected Google Trends search query data from January 2011 to July 2013 for all US states, looking for terms related to bitcoin and its possible clientele.
Based on this data, the researchers constructed four possible categories of users for bitcoin: programming enthusiasts, speculative investors, libertarians and cybercriminals.
Illegal activity and computer programming were positively associated with bitcoin use, but there was no association for libertarian ideology or investment motives.
Previous research was also referenced, leading to the conclusion that the three main motives driving bitcoiners were curiosity, profit and political ideology. Yelowitz and Wilson warn that some of the correlations were Â“inherently difficultÂ” to measure due to the sensitivity of bitcoin activity.

Why should someone (not knowledgeable about bitcoin) should start spending hours and hours to learn about bitcoin's concept. Why should that someone start right now?
How about this?Â  a couple minutes
Bitcoin Basic Concepts
Â•Bitcoin is a shared ledger system and the current state of the ledger is determined by a decentralized consensus.
Â•Bitcoin "mining" is the process of adding transactions to the ledger and is done by solving math problems that take substantial computational power.
Â•The "consensus" is achieved by users and "miners" deciding to run compatible versions of the software and enforcing the consensus rules.
Â•Users can run "nodes" using peer-2-peer connections that shares the ledger.
Â•Nodes enforce the rules by only broadcasting transactions and sections of the ledger that fit within the consensus rules.
Â•A user can verify the shared ledger took a huge amount of computational power to create as a way of trusting it is real.
Â•Miners get transaction fees and "block rewards" as an incentive to use their computer power.
Â•The "rewards" are a way to initially distribute the currency and are cut in half about every 4 years.
Â•Bitcoin addresses are secure because the numbers are so large that all the computers in the world cannot come close to cracking it.

Hello Bitcoiners!
Bitcoin Black Friday officially launches on Nov. 29th.
This is the second annual event. We had a Bitcoin Black Friday last year and had about 75 participating merchants. Here's a rundown of Bitcoin Friday results from last year.
http://codinginmysleep.com/bitcoin-friday-results/
Everyone had a great day... Let's do it again, but bigger!
This year we're aiming to get 500 (Yes, I said 500) merchants signed up and offering deals on their websites ONLY for Bitcoin users ONLY on November 29th.
For those of you who didn't participate last year, Bitcoin Friday is a one day sale two weeks before the great American pre-holiday sale: Black Friday. It is a chance to prove a couple things:
Bitcoin is not only used for buying drugs. Huge this year with all the news coverage of the Silk Road closure.
People will spend bitcoins, and not only hoard them.
That the Bitcoin community treasures its Bitcoin merchants and appreciates their work and contribution to the Bitcoin economy.
Last year we had a couple spontaneous Bitcoin Friday parties erupt (looking at you Bitcoin Kiez and Room77
). This year Bitcoin Friday will hopefully be sending packages of goodies (from BF participating merchants!) to groups that host Bitcoin Black Friday parties. Think Bitcoin Friday t-shirts, Alpaca socks, and other Bitcoin-related items. If you're interested in hosting a BBF party, let me know over PM. I'll be promoting this portion of Bitcoin Black Friday more in the next week.
So, I'd love some feedback on how the project has developed, please reply below with suggestions for this year's sale!
If you're interested in signing up for an alert when the sale begins, or listing as a merchant (it's free!) go to our website:
